{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3756906,"name":"Brody Anderson","username":"flamekeeper","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/flamekeeper/{size}/267435_2.png","created_at":"2025-10-07T13:23:35.982Z","cooked":"

I’m currently coding our climber, which is an everybot style climber. It has two NEOs with a 50:1 gear ratio (I think, might be different though), controlling a winch to the climbing mechanism

During driving, the climber has snapped off or physically pulled out its own hex shaft a few times now due to the low time between getting off the ground and hitting our hard stop. I was trying to think of solutions, and I thought of getting the load on the motors to decide when to cut off the button. Is this idea feasible?

I can’t get the current test code in right now since I’m at school, but the calculations look a bit like this:

double i1 = Math.max(0.0, climbMotor.getOutputCurrent() - FREE_CURRENT);
double i2 = Math.max(0.0, climbMotorFollow.getOutputCurrent() - FREE_CURRENT);
//Free current should be the no-load current for a NEO

double tauMotor1 = KT * i1;
double tauMotor2 = KT * i2;
//KT should be the NEO empirical torque contant

double tauOutTotal = (tauMotor1 + tauMotor2) * GEAR_RATIO * EFFICIENCY;

double force = tauOutTotal / DRUM_RADIUS;

return force / G;

I haven’t messed much with currents in the past so I’m not sure if this is missing anything or has any big redundancies, if anyone is able to give advice on this it would be greatly appreciated

I don’t think there is anything wrong with pursuing this method for educational reasons, and perhaps other people can weight in on whether you’re on the right track for this sort of solution. However, I’m not sure I’d recommend it over other options.

You probably have way more torque than needed. Consider the following solutions:

  1. Only use 1 motor or a less aggressive gear ratio. With the right gear ratio, I would be surprised if one motor wasn’t enough. We climb pretty quickly on a single motor geared 36:1.
  2. Apply some aggressive current limits, as this will limit torque. Consider lowering the current limit until you can no longer climb. Then, use the lowest limit that still gives you the performance desired.

Another catergory of solutions would be to limit the motion through the use of sensors. This would prevent your robot from being the hard stop for the motion. You could do either of the following:

  1. Install a limit switch or hall effect sensor to detect when the motor should stop.
  2. Use the relative internal motor sensors or an external absolute encoder to implement position control and command your motors to a set position.

Doing the formal force and load calculations seems like a fun project which ive never done, but we did a much more simple version this year to determine when we took an algae off the reef.

Our logic had a current threshold which we determined experimentally and a threshold count. If the current broke the threshold for a certain number of loops it meant we had an algae in our intake and we automatically stopped. It worked quite well:

github.com/FRC-Team-8513-Sisters-1st/2025-RobotCode

2025-RobotCode/src/main/java/frc/robot/Subsystems/Algae.java

    2. 
          
  2.         algaeController.setSetpoint(algaeMotor1.getEncoder().getPosition());
    3.

    4. 
          
  4.     algaeMotor1.set(-1);
    5. 
          
  5. }
    6. 
          
  6. if (algaeState == AlgaeIntakeStates.stationary) {
    7. 
          
  7.     algaeOutFirstTime = true;
    8.

    9.

    10.

    12. 
          
  12.     currentLimitBrokenCount++;
    13.

    21.

    22.

suPURDUEperAndy:

Apply some aggressive current limits, as this will limit torque. Consider lowering the current limit until you can no longer climb. Then, use the lowest limit that still gives you the performance desired.

That’s probably a lot better of a solution thank you. I guess I was over thinking this a little bit lol, thank you both I’ll be sure to try the other current logic if the limits end up not working

The solution @Owen_Busler posted is also an effective method. We used something similar for our algae intake. It can be hard to balance response time and filtering out false positives (our algae mech had a current spike when it kicked on).

After posting my response, I realized that you probably didn’t want to reduce the gear ratio or number of motors because both of those things help you to stay climbed with motors in brake mode. Hopefully the current limits work for you!
